Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Provably Safe Automotive Cyber-Physical Systems with Humans-in-the-Loop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on the formal design of semi-autonomous automotive Cyber Physical Systems (CPS). Rather than disconnecting the driver from the vehicle, the goal is to obtain a vehicle where the degree of autonomy is continuously changed in real-time as a function of certified uncertainty ranges for driver behavior and environment reconstruction. The highly integrated research plan will advance the science and engineering for CPS by developing methods for (1) reconstructing 3D scenes which incorporate high-level topological and low-level metric information, (2) extracting driver behavioral models from large datasets using geometry, reasoning and inferences, (3) designing provably-safe control schemes which trade-off real-time feasibility and conservatism by using the evidence collected during actual driving.

Assisting humans in controlling complex and safety-critical systems is a global challenge. In order to improve the safety of human-operated CPS we need to provide guarantees in the reconstruction of the environment where the humans and the CPS operate, and to develop control systems that use predictive cognitive models of the human when interacting with the CPS. A successful and integrated research in both areas will impact not only the automotive sector but many other human-operated systems. These include telesurgery, homeland security, assisted rehabilitation, power networks, environmental monitoring, and all transportation CPS. Graduate, undergraduate and underrepresented engineering students will benefit through classroom instruction, involvement in the research and a continuous interaction with industrial partners who are leaders in the field of assisted driving.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the formal design of semi-autonomous automotive Cyber Physical Systems (CPS).  Rather than disconnecting the driver from the vehicle, the goal is to obtain a vehicle where the degree of autonomy is continuously changed in real-time as a function of certified uncertainty ranges in driver behavior and environment reconstruction.

Our research has advanced science and engineering for CPS by developing methods for (1) reconstructing 3D scenes which incorporate high-level topological and low-level metric information, (2) extracting driver behavioral models from large datasets using geometry, reasoning and inferences, (3) designing provably-safe control schemes which trade-off real-time feasibility and conservatism by using the evidence collected during actual driving.


The following KEY outcomes resulted from this award.

* We sought to better understand driver perception of complex, dynamic, real-world environments.  To this end, we characterized how people keep track of many objects moving around them using rich computational models, how they use their limited cognitive capacity to remember individual objects and the overall structure of a scene, and how human cognition uses constraints from Newtonian mechanics to better extrapolate the trajectories of moving objects.  Altogether, these experiments allowed us to specify formal probabilistic models of human perception and prediction of richly structured, uncertain, dynamic environments such as those encountered by drivers.
* We developed novel mathematical tools for the identification and tracking of obstacles in an environment. These tools rely on techniques from topological data analysis in order to identify robust features from a probability of occupancy map. The proposed methodology quantifies robustness by tracking the changes on the number of obstacles detected as a function of perturbation to the data. The extension of this approach to dynamic scenarios was done by integrating the topological descriptors with a model-based filtering framework. 
* We developed advanced control strategies for the safe operation of the automotive CPS in the face of uncertainty imposed by the driver's actions and the environment. We utilized probabilistic optimization-based control techniques which allow us to systematically manage the trade-off between collision risk and conservatism. Uncertainty in the driving scene was learnt from actual driving data. The real-time feasibility of our approaches was shown through autonomous driving experiments on a passenger vehicle running embedded processors with moderate computing power.


Assisting humans in controlling complex and safety-critical systems is a global challenge. In order to improve the safety of human-operated CPS we need to provide guarantees in the reconstruction of the environment where the humans and the CPS operate, and to develop control systems which use predictive cognitive models of the human when interacting with the CPS. Our project has only scraped the surface of what is a probably one of the biggest challenge on modern society: the seamless and safe integration of humans and robots. This is of outmost importance not only in the automotive sector but many other human-operated systems. These include tele-surgery, homeland security, assisted rehabilitations, power networks, environmental monitoring, and any transportation CPS. Post-graduate, graduate and undergraduate students have enormously benefitted from this proposal through classroom instruction, involvement in the research and a continuous interaction with industrial partners.
